qas.question: When did surface-mount become a commonly used manufacturing process?
What did the new components with end tabs replace?
What improvement is possible with surface-mounting that enables higher production and lower labor costs?
Is it the chip or the package that influences the price of an SMD more?
What kind of technology emerged in the 1950s?
What became widely used in the 2090s?
What was redesigned to have small plastic tabs?
What lends itself well to a low degree of automation?

plausible_answers.text: Some wire-ended components, such as 1N4148 small-signal switch diodes

qas.question: What are more expensive than SMD equivalents?

context: <b5_0><b6_0>Surface-mount technology<b6_0/><b5_0/> emerged in the 1960s, gained momentum in the early 1980s and became widely used by the <a0_0>mid-1990s<a0_0/>. <b7_0>Components<b7_0/> were mechanically redesigned to have small metal tabs or end caps that could be soldered directly onto the PCB surface, instead of <a1_0>wire leads<a1_0/> to pass through holes. Components became much smaller and component placement on both sides of the board became more common than with through-hole mounting, allowing much smaller PCB assemblies with much higher circuit densities. <b8_0>Surface mounting<b8_0/> lends itself well to a high degree of <a2_0>automation<a2_0/>, reducing labor costs and greatly increasing production rates. Components can be supplied mounted on carrier tapes. Surface mount components can be about one-quarter to one-tenth of the size and weight of through-hole components, and passive components much cheaper; prices of semiconductor <a3_0>surface mount devices<a3_0/> (SMDs) are determined more by the <a4_0>chip<a4_0/> itself than the package, with little price advantage over larger packages. <b9_0>Some wire-ended components, such as 1N4148 small-signal switch diodes<b9_0/>, are actually significantly cheaper than SMD equivalents.
